conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the suitcase and use the conditions for equilibrium to find the angle θ and the coefficient of friction μ.
Identify the forces acting on the suitcase: The weight of the suitcase, W = mg = 15 × 10 = 150 N.
The tension in the pull, T.
Resolve the pull into horizontal and vertical components: The horizontal component of the pull is T cos θ.
The vertical component of the pull is T sin θ.
Set up the equations for equilibrium: Vertical equilibrium: The vertical component of the pull and the normal force must balance the weight of the suitcase.
Vertical equilibrium equation is N + T sin θ = W.
Horizontal equilibrium equation is T cos θ = μN.

premise: N + T sin θ = W and T cos θ = μN
conclusion: Substitute N from the vertical equilibrium equation into the horizontal equilibrium equation: T cos θ = μ (W - T sin θ).

premise: T cos θ = μ (W - T sin θ)
conclusion: Rearrange to solve for T: T (cos θ + μ sin θ) = μW.

premise: T (cos θ + μ sin θ) = μW
conclusion: T = μW / (cos θ + μ sin θ).
Use the given minimum pull T = 90 N to find θ and μ.

premise: T = μW / (cos θ + μ sin θ) and T = 90 N

conclusion: Using the condition for the minimum value of the pull, we can use the formula for the minimum force required to move an object up an incline, which in this case is the frictional force.
